abstracts.cdata!:
Project outcome is rated highly
            satisfactory and project sustainability is highly likely.
            world Bank performance is adjudged as satisfactory while
            Borrower satisfaction is regarded as highly satisfactory.
            Lessons learned include the following: During project
            preparation to the appraisal stage, there is a need to
            combine supply (State) and demand-driven (market )
            interventions, gauge timely (appropriate) project
            implementation, include proper targeting criteria and
            performance indicators at the onset of project
            implementation, and use a flexible project design. During
            project implementation, ensure enabling conditions, pilot
            and evaluate before taking to scale, staff to build robust
            institutions, set up an appropriate legal and regulatory
            framework, build learning systems, ensure ownership at the
            outset of project implementation, arrange for appropriate
            dissemination and cross-fertilization, put in place a timely
            conceived exit strategy, and provide continuity in project
            management and supervision. At project completion, there is
            a need to continuously and consistently address pending
            issues in the education sector. For example, despite project
            efforts and investments, some inequities worsened throughout
            the life of the project, mainly due to exogenous factors
            benefiting private-paid secondary schools (outside the
            project's interventions) over the municipal and private
            subsidized ones. This points out that project objectives
            still need to be achieved after completion.

repnme.cdata!:
Chile - Secondary Education Quality
            Improvement Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The Secondary Education Quality
            Improvement Project seeks to improve the internal and
            external efficiency, quality, and equity of all the
            municipal and government-subsidized private secondary
            schools, and to strengthen sectoral managerial capacity. The
            project will improve external efficiency by: 1) establishing
            a curriculum planning and evaluation unit to reformulate the
            subject-based curriculum, for both the scientific-humanistic
            and technical-vocational secondary schools; 2) developing
            evaluation capacity to monitor the consistency between the
            recommended and the learned curriculum; 3) establishing
            alternative curricular activities for socially and
            educationally at-risk secondary students; 4) providing
            incentives to strengthen the linkages between targeted
            technical-vocational schools and the private sector in
            curriculum development, skill certification, in-service
            teacher training, and the use of physical facilities. The
            project will improve quality, equity, and internal
            efficiency by: 1) providing in-service teacher training to
            change the predominantly one-dimensional teaching format
            based mainly on rote learning and dictation, to more
            interactive methods; 2) establishing a fund to promote the
            design and implementation of school-based educational
            development projects; and 3) providing educational resources
            in a targeted manner. Finally, the project will also include
            components to strengthen sectoral managerial capacity.
